results.description:
Got renters? Sooner or later you’ll have to collect unpaid water bills. Learn how at the next:  Savvy Women Investors Meeting             

Special presentation by Sal Catalano from

RentCourt.com

 PLEASE NOTE OUR NEW MEETING LOCATION!  Meet us on Wednesday, May 4, at 6:30 p.m. at the 

Fuji Buffet and Grill

, 1012 Taylor Ave., Towson, MD 21286.  (Map) 

FREE admission for Baltimore REIA members. Just $19 for non-members.

Everyone pays for their own meal. When renters leave with unpaid water bills, it can mean hundreds of dollars down the drain for you. Why? Because the bill sticks with your property, not the renter.  So how can you prevail in rent court and recover the money that’s owed you? It hasn’t gotten any easier, due to a recent ruling by the Court of Special Appeals. Even if your lease says “water bills can be collected as additional rent,” judges may rule against you.  Guest speaker Sal Catalfano of RentCourt.com, as well as our own Janet Tonkins, will show you how to add new language to help counteract the court’s decision. This language is essential for new leases, and you can include it in an addendum when your tenants renew their current leases. 

About Sal Catalfano.  Besides his affiliation withRentCourt.com, Sal is a member of the Baltimore City Rent Court Committee and the Baltimore City Rent Escrow Committee. Sal knows his stuff, and he’ll share his knowledge with you. If you have renters now or ever will, don’t miss this meeting!

Ladies, the Savvy Women Investors Meeting was created especially for you. Offering knowledge, support, food, and fun, SWIM is perfect for newbies seeking the path to success… experienced investors striving for the next level… and all women who are eager to learn and network.  Join us! Everyone must buy a meal. The restaurant needs to make money, just as we investors do. Admission is FREE for Baltimore REIA members. Non-members pay $19 to help cover our marketing and meeting costs. You can pay at the door, but why not spend less time in line and more time networking?  Sign up now: 

 To avoid the non-member charge and gain many other benefits, 

join Baltimore REIA now

.  Take our $1 Test-Drive for 30 days, or sign up for a full year for just $179 and get our FREE welcome kit with $197 worth of DVDs.  QUESTIONS?  Contact Janet Tonkins, SWIM Coordinator, at[masked] or

[masked]

.  

 Janet also teaches our 

“Real Estate Rental Cash Machine”

 class.  Check it out. See you at SWIM! P.S. Want even more education from Baltimore REIA? With one-on-one, personal attention? Discover our 

Inner Circle

 program. 

 www.BaltimoreREIA.com
results.name: Saavy Women Investors Meeting

results.description:
In this seminar we explore the concept of non-duality in healing.  Can we experience the non-dual state at will and use this space of consciousness to heal both ourselves and others?  

We start with this question and go on to explore the following topics:

-The difference between absolute and relative healing.

-The concept of the ever-present witnessing awareness.

-How to drop down into the witnessing state of consciousness and energy.

-The similarities between non-dual awareness and the quantum void.

-Healing from non-dual consciousness or the quantum void.

-Learning and experiencing techniques to heal from non-dual awareness.

-Learning meditations that allow for the recognition of non-dual consciousness.

This seminar will help in deepening your spiritual and healing practice.  It will give a larger context to the activities and service you provide to the world.

Please bring meditation cushion, notebook, pens, and/or pencils as needed.

The cost is $55 and is limited to 20 people. Early registration is required. 

To register:  http://nourishing-journey.com/journey/event-registration/ 

**(click on drop down arrow to select workshop) 


About Gene:


Gene Ang, Ph.D. has a healing practice based in Thousand Oaks, California and sees clients for Reconnective Healing, the Reconnection, Pranic Healing, Vortex Healing, and Shamanic Healing. In addition, he teaches a number of seminars that focus on the integration of science, spirituality, and healing. Gene travels around the United States facilitating healing sessions and workshops.

Gene received his BA from Stanford in Human Biology and Philosophy/Religious Studies, and was formally trained as a Neurobiologist at Yale where he earned his doctorate in basic mechanisms of how the brain develops followed by a post-doctoral fellowship on how ultrasound can affect the developing cerebral cortex.

After his post-doctoral fellowship, Gene decided to step into the role of a facilitator of healing in order to directly interact with helping people.

Most of his work centers around the use of subtle energy to help align the subtle energy body, its channels, meridians, and energy centers to help restore balance and harmony so that healing can occur whether it be physical, emotional, mental, and/or spiritual.

Gene doesn't see himself as the healer but simply as part of the interconnectedness that occurs when facilitator, client, and Source/Love/God interact to bring healing forth. He sees his teaching engagements and seminars as an extension of this interaction that occurs on multiple dimensions to bring wholeness and understanding to all involved.

Website: www.geneang.com
results.how_to_find_us: Enter Dunkin Donuts driveway: Nourishing Journey, LLC is behind Dunkin Donuts, 3rd doorway on the right
results.name: Non-Dual Healing with Gene Ang, Ph.D.

results.description:
Goh's Kung Fu offers a unique tai chi experience on Wednesday nights.  Our tai chi students work directly with Sifu Kevin learning forms, strengthening exercises and movement details.

Tai chi is an internal style practiced by millions of people today, this low impact exercise regulates the central nervous system and helps to relieve mental and emotional stress.  Tai Chi training emphasizes body coordination, balance, relaxation, abdominal breathing and smoothness.  It is practiced as a preventative exercise for stress, high blood pressure and heart problems.


Classes are $50.00/month and meet every Wednesday night.  1 free trial class.
results.how_to_find_us: Goh's Kung Fu is conveniently located 1 mile south of the beltway (exit 31).  We are on Harford Road across from the Parkville Shopping Center.
results.name: Practice Tai Chi at Goh's Kung Fu

results.description:
Santi White, better known by her stage name Santigold, is an American singer and producer

. Her debut album, Santogold, including the singles "Creator" and "L.E.S. Artistes", received very favourable reviews in 2008.

Who Be Lovin Me2016 

Can't Get Enough of Myself2016 

SongsDisparate Youth2012

L.E.S Artistes2008 

Shove It2008 


http://www.baltimoresoundstage.com/event/1078011-santigold-we-buy-gold-tour-baltimore/ 

"I don't make music for myself," says Santigold, matter-of-factly. "I pay a lot of attention to that -- making music that's liked by more people than just myself." In a scene driven by bravado, few musicians would ruminate on the Zen-like balance behind creating truly gratifying art. But exploring that intersection between integrity and intrigue has always been central to this idiosyncratic musician's appeal. That, in turn, has culminated in her latest release, '99¢' (out January 22, 2016), an often-playful satire on the singer's "brand." 

"The '99¢' album cover features me shrink-wrapped among a cluttered mess of things -- my life in a bag," she explains. "It is about how everything is a packaged product for sale: how we package ourselves, our lives, our relationships." 

We first heard Santigold's outspoken, unmistakable voice in 2008 on her vibrant self-titled debut featuring the singles "L.E.S. Artistes" and "Creator," both takedowns about authenticity that won praises from Rolling Stone and Pitchfork alike. Her follow-up, the darker 'Master of My Make-Believe' -- its centerpiece, the post-punk anthem "Disparate Youth" -- hit both Billboard's Dance/Electronic and Top 200 charts upon its release. Where to go from there? 

"When I got off the 'Master of My Make-Believe' tour, I got home and said, 'I want to do something completely different,"' she says. So she created a post-apocalyptic makeup line for Smashbox, designed head-tripping socks for Stance, and popped-up in acting gigs on "The Office" and Adult Swim's "NTSF:SD:SUV::." "I think if I hadn't done all that," she says, "I wouldn't have been prepared to do more music." 

She also spent time with her new son, who's responsible for much of '99¢'s markedly sunnier disposition. "He kinda forces me to go with the flow. That's completely, absolutely the opposite of my natural tendency," she says, laughing. That new perspective is evident right from the album's optimistic, lilting opening track, "Can't Get Enough of Myself." "I was very careful to write lyrics that were bright and worked really hard on that," adds Santigold. "It sometimes doesn't come easy to me, because my sense of humor can get dark." 

It took roughly eight months to manifest her new vision, with assists from a mix of collaborators with poppier visions such as producers Patrick Berger (Robyn, Icona Pop) and John Hill (Florence and the Machine, Charli XCX), alongside eclectic talents known more for globe-trotting sounds such as Vampire Weekend's Rostam Batmanglij and TV on the Radio's Dave Sitek. She went into the studio with them intending to make a fun record. "My last record had a seriousness to it," she says. "This time around, it's more playful -- but still a commentary." 

'99¢' came together primarily in New York City and Los Angeles, with a stint in Jamaica, where Santigold likes to do her lyrical heavy-lifting. "I have a place there in a tropical forest, with a balcony overlooking endless trees, and in the horizon, the ocean," she says. "You get up at seven in the morning, and the lyrics just pour out." Her vantage may have shifted, but '99¢' remains grounded in her aural anchors: bold rhythms, glitched-out melodies, and morphing global sounds. 

Buoyancy was important to her, but so was capturing a depth of sounds and emotions. As such, life-affirming exhortations like the African-beatific "Banshee" and the new-wave "Rendezvous Girl" coexist alongside ethereal, existential tracks such as "Chasing Shadows," "Before the Fire" (co-written with indie-soul artist Sam Dew), and "Walking in a Circle." The latter "was about how I sometimes feel as an artist in this climate. Feeling stuck," she says. "It's about this struggle to find a fun place." 

Today, any of her dissents veer toward the contemplative. "I wanted to write some songs that felt very personal," she says. "Before Santigold, in my other band, I used to write songs like journal entries. And I tried to write a couple of songs on this record where it was really about me and my experience." Though, in true Santigold form, she balances the introspective moments with humorous ones in songs like "Who Be Loving Me," a lighthearted boast about fan adoration, produced by Zeds Dead and featuring ILoveMakonnen. 

"You could go around being annoyed all the time, or you can go, 'This is crazy and actually funny.' Then you can play around with it, and make great art," she says. "This album has required me to be more open, less of a perfectionist." Ironically, that's made the prismatic '99¢' her most ambitious album to date. "I realize that my work is a collage," she says. "And I can pretty much take that anywhere."

results.name: Santigold @ Baltimore Soundstage in Baltimore, MD

results.description:
What is Open Hack night?

The Baltimore Hackerspace Open Hack night is an opportunity. It's an opportunity to show off your newest idea, creation, or prototype, meet people with similar or different skill sets, and an opportunity to have a peer review or brainstorming session done on your idea. It's a great way to get your feet wet in the hackerspace that's right around the corner. Everyone is welcome to come, seek advice, stay, collaborate, and contribute -- think of it as a scheduled time when everyone meets to help out everyone else. The Baltimore Hackerspace is an open-space, meaning members come and go, work on projects, and collaborate with other members as they please.
results.how_to_find_us: 6410 Landay Ave, Baltimore MD 21237
results.name: Open Hack Night

results.description:
This exciting event will mark the end of the 5th cycle of our FabSLAM program where teams compete to create innovative and creative products in response to a digital fabrication challenge. Join us to check out all of the awesome projects and meet the makers! 

FabSLAM is a multi-week, team-based, digital fabrication competition where youth learn and practice design, iteration, and rapid prototyping skills primarily focused on 3D Design and 3D Printing. A challenge theme is presented and each team works to develop a product that fits the theme and meets any accompanying requirements. 

Each team works with a Coach to help guide the team through the challenge and aid in documentation. FabSLAM culminates in a FabSLAM Showcase where teams will present their products to a panel of judges and a public audience for review and feedback.
results.name: FabSLAM Showcase

Buoyancy was important to her, but so was capturing a depth of sounds and emotions. As such, life-affirming exhortations like the African-beatific "Banshee" and the new-wave "Rendezvous Girl" coexist alongside ethereal, existential tracks such as "Chasing Shadows," "Before the Fire" (co-written with indie-soul artist Sam Dew), and "Walking in a Circle." The latter "was about how I sometimes feel as an artist in this climate. Feeling stuck," she says. "It's about this struggle to find a fun place." 

Today, any of her dissents veer toward the contemplative. "I wanted to write some songs that felt very personal," she says. "Before Santigold, in my other band, I used to write songs like journal entries. And I tried to write a couple of songs on this record where it was really about me and my experience." Though, in true Santigold form, she balances the introspective moments with humorous ones in songs like "Who Be Loving Me," a lighthearted boast about fan adoration, produced by Zeds Dead and featuring ILoveMakonnen. 

"You could go around being annoyed all the time, or you can go, 'This is crazy and actually funny.' Then you can play around with it, and make great art," she says. "This album has required me to be more open, less of a perfectionist." Ironically, that's made the prismatic '99¢' her most ambitious album to date. "I realize that my work is a collage," she says. "And I can pretty much take that anywhere."

results.description:
Democracies have repeatedly been criticized for their corruption.  Those which have been overthrown by dictators -- the dictators generally cite this corruption as a rationale for their overthrow (Caesar, Cromwell, Napoleon, Mussolini, Hitler, Putin). 

However, dictatorships, and single party states, tend to be even more susceptible to corruption than democracies are.  Russia under Putin has notable corruption -- his ascension only changed who the cronies are.  China under communist party rule is one of the more corrupt countries in the world, and this is not just private corruption -- the "success" of every 5 year plan to officially meet its targets is legendary.

The exception is moralists and theocrats -- the Taliban was less corrupt than its predecessors or successors in Afghanistan, and the period where the Jacobins ruled France post-revolution was less corrupt.  But these moralizers tend to engage in "moral" oppression and bloodbaths that make mere corruption seem idyllic. 

Corruption occurs because people with "interests", either ideological/political/religious or monetary, find it beneficial to skew the playing field unevenly to their favor.  And people find ways to exercise these "interests" in every poitical system.

The three credible prescriptions I have seen to address this effect are:

Karl Popper:  Open societies are responsive to correct failings -- if the corruption and skewing is too detrimental, the people will change policies to limit it.  Democracy, because it has a stronger feedback loop than any other form of govt, is least susceptible to corruption.

Good Government advocates: radical openness and sunshine limits the potential for corruption

Libertarian:  limit the role of government, and this limits the scope for corruption

So, how critical is courruption for our democracy, can democracy survive it, and is there a solution?

Plan to arrive at least 15 minutes ahead of time if you want to get food.  Coffee in particular is only available before 7, so late arrivers will have to do without.

results.description:
Hello Laughter Friends!

I am delighted to bring some Laughter Yoga energy to Baltimore!

Let's transform ourselves through laughter! Join me for some wellness laughter at the Ruscombe Mansion Yoga Room where we will fill the space with vibrant laughter energy! ----------

New to Laughter Yoga? Laughter Yoga is not a fad.

Laughter Yoga is celebrating it's 21st Anniversary this year and is practiced in 105 countries and at over 6000 laughter clubs.

LY is the combination of laughter exercises + deep yoga breathing+mindfulness meditation.

NO YOGA POSES- but don't worry, this is still considered an aerobic workout. That said, all the exercises are very easy to follow, NO EXPERIENCE NECESSARY. You will burn calories, you will give your diaphragm a good work out and you will leave feeling great, no exaggeration.

We practice laughing for the sake of laughing to benefit our health. We don't use comedy or jokes to provoke the laughter. Instead, you will be guided by a Laughter Yoga professional into following some fun & simple laughter exercises which include clapping, chanting, singing, dancing and of course, LAUGHING. We will have you giggling in no time. Everyone will feel uplifted and energized after the session.

Laughter reduces feelings of stress, anxiety and depression. Laughter opens up the blood vessels, increases your oxygen levels to the body and brain and boosts the immune system. Did you know that:

- the Navy uses LY to reduce post traumatic stress syndrome?

- Cancer patients at the Mayo clinic use LY to build up their immunities and to increase T-cells?

- Research at U of MD Medical Center has shown that LY increases the net oxygen to the body, which expands the arteries to help blood flow, helping to regulate blood pressure?

-The American Heart&Stroke Association uses Laughter Yoga to promote a healthy heart and reduce risks of stroke and heart attack.

- Laughter brings us the the present moment and helps to reduce chronic pain

-LY helps us face life's challenges and helps us build positive behaviors and resilience.

Get strong, get laughing!

Laughter Yoga is non-religious and non-political. Laughter Club meetings are open to all- ages 12 and up.

If you are able to do light aerobic activity, you can easily participate in Laughter Yoga. If you are unable to perform standing exercises, you can do them seated and we will come to you.

Curious to know more about Laughter Yoga and what happens at a laughter session? Here is a recent article from Philly voice:

http://www.phillyvoice.com/we-tried-it-learning-laugh-it-laughter-yoga/ Wear comfortable clothing and pack a water bottle. ( Lots of Laughter makes you thirsty : ) We thank you for arriving 10 mins. early to sign in and so that we can start on time.

COST: $10.00/person , which can be paid at the door or on this meetup site

but please RSVP here to let me know that you will be joining the session, thanks.

I look forward to laughing with you soon!

Lightness & Laughter,

Alexa Alexa Drubay

www.laughteryogawithalexa.com

Directions:

http://www.ruscombe.org/directionstoruscombe.html
results.name: Laughter Yoga with Alexa at the Ruscombe Mansion in Baltimore

results.description:
What: This is an open ongoing mindfulness meditation group for both beginners and experienced practitioners.

While the forms of meditation we practice are rooted in Buddhist teachings, the study and practice of mindfulness and insight meditation is applicable to anyone from any background or religion, and all are welcome.

These teachings are available to all. Although a $10 donation is suggested, donations are not required for attendance.


Each class will include: guided meditation, instruction, opportunities to practice, and time for discussion, questions and answers.

When and where: We meet every Wednesday from 7:30-9:00 p.m. at Centennial High School, 4300 Centennial Lane, Ellicott City, MD, 21042, room 406. Please arrive early to settle into your seats - we start right at 7:30 p.m. [Note: Class will be canceled on days that the school is closed.]

We practice Insight Meditation, a style of meditation that helps the mind attain deeper levels of calm concentration through sustained attention on the breath, then combines this with the crucial aspect of insight through contemplation of the mind and body and all of their changing and impermanent senses, emotions and thoughts. Insight Meditation trains us to live more fully in the present moment, enables us to experience life from a greater stillness, and aids us in relating to both ourselves and others with increased clarity, compassion, calmness and creativity, and less fear, anxiety and stress.

Along with these and a long list of other psychological benefits, meditation has also been shown to reduce stress hormones in the body, lower blood pressure, reduce anxiety, alleviate depression and boost the immune system.

Teacher:

Stan Eisenstein, a high school physics teacher who has been meditating for 25 years and has been practicing Insight Meditation since 2004. Stan is a mentor with the Insight Meditation Community of Washington (IMCW) and is a graduate of the Meditation Teacher Training Institute, a two-year certification program with senior Insight teachers Tara Brach, Jonathan Foust, Hugh Byrne, and Pat Coffey. He also teaches Mindfulness Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) and Mindfulness Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT). Stan also earned a Masters of Social Work in 1998.

Centennial High School Parking (see map below) - September through June:

If coming to the school from the South (Route 108) side of Centennial Lane, make a left into the bus loop just as you reach the school. Immediately on your left is a drive to a parking lot on the south/left side of the school. Park in this lot and follow the signs to room 406.

If coming to the school from the North (Route 40) side of Centennial Lane, make a right into the bus loop just as you finish passing the school. Immediately on your left is a drive to a parking lot on the south/left side of the school. Park in this lot and follow the signs to room 406.

Suggestions:

1. There are plenty of chairs, but if you prefer to sit on the floor, which is carpeted, please bring a hard pillow or zafu, since, when meditating, it is recommended that your hips be higher than your knees. If you have never tried sitting on the floor during meditation, it is highly recommended that you try the chair first, then practice sitting on the floor at home until you are comfortable.

2. If you have any back issues, please bring a pillow or cushion to place behind you.

3. The chairs are hard, so you may wish to bring a cushion with you to sit on.

4. Please remember to turn off your cell phones before entering the room.

5. Please try not to wear any perfume to the sit, as it can be quite distracting to others. Also, with respect to those who may be allergic, we do not use incense.

6. The group is not recommended for those under age 13.

Please feel free to contact Stan Eisenstein at [masked] if you have any questions.

Game Overview
90,000 B.C. — A great ice age is fast approaching. Another titanic struggle for global supremacy has unwittingly commenced between the varying animal species.
Dominant Species is a game that abstractly recreates a tiny portion of ancient history: the ponderous encroachment of an ice age and what that entails for the living creatures trying to adapt to the slowly-changing earth.
Each player will assume the role of one of six major animal classes—mammal, reptile, bird, amphibian, arachnid, or insect. Each begins the game more or less in a state of natural balance in relation to one another. But that won’t last: It is indeed "survival of the fittest".
results.name: Dominant Species

The citizens of the gnome enclave of Whistledown in distant Varisia are being kidnapped by malevolent creatures that stalk the night. You are sent there by the Pathfinder Society to see if this sudden surge of vile activity is linked to the rumors of a hidden tomb near Whistledown that holds the body of a famed Osirion concubine. Can you save the town of Whistledown from certain doom and find the lost tomb of the ancient concubine?

Terror at Whistledown is part 3 of the Echoes of the Everwar series. Parts 1, 2, and 3 can be played in any order and part 4 must be played last. Look for part 4, Pathfinder Society Scenario #53: The Faithless Dead, in June 2010.

- remove blocked negative energy

Meetup agenda:

- Introduction to the Law of Attraction (LOA) or help you determine what is blocking the LOA from working for you 

- Help you set goals/dreams with an action plan 

- Measure your energy field

- Help sync your goal to your subconscious mind

- Energetic healing with B.E.S.T

Case Study

  A woman was experiencing severe pain in her knee. It would swell up for a few days, then go back down, and then swell up for a week. After a few weeks of excruciating pain, the woman went to a doctor. The doctor injected cortisone into her knee and it made the pain go away.

  A few months later the cortisone wore off and her knee hurt even more than it originally did. The doctor injected more cortisone and it was good for another few months. When her knee swelled up again it tore the meniscus of the knee and she was told she would need surgery. After surgery her knee was locked and was very painful. The doctor reported the surgery wasn’t a success and that she would need a knee replacement.

She wanted to get a second opinion and got a B.E.S.T. treatment. She was told that her knee swelling was a direct response to a past negative experience. The feeling associated with the experience was identified, contact points were made and the interference was removed. Upon standing up from the adjustment table her knee was 95% better. Tears of joy rolled down her face as she walked around the room. Her husband was in disbelief and even more shocked at the speed in which her own body repaired her knee.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Dr. Sue Morter explains it as; the body reveals short-circuited neurological patterns as a result of unresolved subconscious emotional issues, affecting all systems required for health and wholeness.  Those patterns can be demonstrated as tight muscles, dysfunctional organs or glands, emotional stress or depression type reactions.  By accessing areas of the brain through a pressure point type therapy, that is, touching certain points around the head and body in a specific sequence, while having you think about certain memory stresses, the body begins to reconnect the circuitry with the brain. Clinical experience has shown that by stimulating these specific pressure points as part of the B.E.S.T. procedure, your body can not only begin to feel better, but will actually begin to repair and rebuild.

  For example, if you experience a physical or emotional trauma your body goes into flight or fight mode. Once this circumstance is over with, your subconscious mind needs to update the current status. If something isn't done to update the current status of the threat and remove the interference created, your body's response is stuck and keeps responding over and over to old information causing that particular system to become exhausted. Exhaustion of a system is what leads to pain, ailments and disease. By touching certain key pressure points in the proper sequence with proper energy and identifying the associated feeling, interference is removed from the subconscious. This results in body balancing, healing of ailments and disease as well as syncing your subconscious mind with your goals. Your body will be ready to run at its optimal potential.

  Let’s discuss someone with muscle tightness. That muscle tightness was appropriate for a previous situation but is no longer needed at the present time. If a muscle is tight for too long it will cause exhaustion of systems and organs and that will change the way they function. This is observed when someone faces a physical or emotional trauma which causes the mind/body to go into fight or flight mode. If your neurological patterns aren’t updated after the stress and you continue to be in fight or flight mode your health will deteriorate.

  B.E.S.T. is updating how your past experience is stored in the subconscious mind. This adjustment is not telling the person to forget the memory, but instead neutralizing the interference associated with the negative experience.

  The path toward permanent relief must include finding the root of the pain or distress. Often, the actual cause is not obvious, because pain can be located in one part of the body while the cause may be located in another. This is why the western medicine practice of taking a pill to stop symptoms is doing more harm than good. Symptoms from a headache, high blood pressure, inability to lose weight and rashes are just a few of the ways your body is trying to tell you something isn’t right. 

  Cause of distress occurs from three areas: trauma, toxicity, and thoughts. This means stress from injury, dietary insufficiencies, or emotional reactions that cause interference in your body. In all cases, the actual cause of pain or distress must be identified and corrected so symptoms do not return.  With a B.E.S.T. treatment you will be able to identify the feeling behind the distress and neutralize it. 

  There is active and passive healing. The western world of medicine is run as passive healing. Take this pill to make the symptoms go away, is a total disregard to the cause of the symptoms and what your body is trying to tell you. B.E.S.T. is an active healing process. You must do something in order to get better.

  Through daily changes in the choices you make, you can dramatically change your health and life. Other components to active healing are forgiveness, abdominal breathing, and the Morter March. Forgiveness is very important. In order to move forward in life you need to let go of all negative emotions in your past and present. Understand that all stress is an unlearned lesson, while disappointment is just things that are not in our control that don’t go as expected. Abdominal breathing helps change the pattern from survival mode to health mode. The Morter March is an exercise that helps improve neurological balance and can be discussed further during your B.E.S.T session.

You need to take 100% responsibility of your life. Everything that happens to you is a product of your thoughts. You attracted the positive and negative people and situations in your life. You have the power to change your life.

 To learn more about balancing your mind/body, unlocking the law of attraction and understanding the power of your thoughts, check out my website at <a>www.subconsciousadjustment.com.</a>

results.description:
This is the story of Father Damien Modeste, priest to his beloved people, the Ojibwe. Modeste, nearing the end of his life, dreads the discovery of his physical identity -- for he is a woman who has lived as a man.

For more than a half century, Father Damien Modeste has served his beloved people, the Ojibwe, on the remote reservation of Little No Horse. To complicate his fears, his quiet life changes when a troubled colleague comes to the reservation to investigate the life of the perplexing, difficult, possibly false saint Sister Leopolda. Father Damien alone knows the strange truth of Sister Leopolda's piety and is faced with the most difficult decision of his life: Should he reveal all he knows and risk everything? Or should he manufacture a protective history though he believes Leopolda's wonder-working is motivated by evil?

results.description:
The Introduction to Eating Psychology Workshop is designed to guide you through your own personal exploration of your Relationship with Food. This workshop is inspirational for anyone looking to gain weight, lose weight, maintain their weight, or who deal with the demons or strengths of body perception. This workshop is helpful for heads of households. This workshop is ideal for anyone balancing lifestyle and meal planning. This workshop will help anyone who eats socially. This workshop is designed to lift the stigma of diet and how it affects you.

Class 1 (May 5th ) In this class you will hear an Introduction to the Psychology of Eating – and how that is different than everything you think you know about dieting.
We will begin the discussion in how emotional attachments and perceptions guide you in your choices – for food and in life.

Class 2 (May 19th) In this class you will begin a more profound and deeper exploration of your Personal Relationship with Food.
Meal planning for life or social events when you have food allergies, medical conditions, or when taking prescription medications.

This class is a blend of lecture and personal work, of group conversation and relative exploration through case studies discussions.

For more information, call[masked], or email Lisa at [masked]. 

To learn more about Lisa please visit www.LK-CEPC.com.
results.name: Introduction to Eating Psychology Workshop 1 of 2

Join us for a special FREE Mother's Day Stroller Strides class! We'll be celebrating moms all morning long with prizes and a few very special giveaways - a gift certificate to LOTUS Wellness Boutique and free photography session with Dontblink Photography by Christine Middleton! Just bring some water, a yoga mat or towel and snacks/toys for your little one(s). This is the perfect time to come try a class and meet some new moms! There will be membership discounts for anyone who joins or purchases a pass by Mother's Day.  You can pre-register for this free class here: https://fit4mom-annapolis.frontdeskhq.com/

After class, join us for a special mom-focused playdate with refreshments, goodies, snacks for our littles and a special Mother's Day craft. 

It's all totally FREE - come join us and let's celebrate being Moms!

Stroller Strides is a total fitness program that moms can do with their babies. It includes power walking and intervals of strength and body toning exercises using exercise tubing, the stroller and the environment. Taught by certified and specially trained fitness instructors, it is a great workout for any level of exerciser. No previous fitness experience needed! Stroller Strides instructors weave songs and activities into the routine designed to entertain and engage baby, while moms are led through a series of exercises specific to her role as mom.  See our website: www.annapolis.fit4mom.com for more info!

The Swellness Center is an indoor open play place for infants and children through age 6. It is a clean, safe, and friendly play environment with opportunities to play with age appropriate toys and musical instruments. The center provides a variety of areas promoting physical, social, cultural and educational activities through several rooms, each with a different theme.

- There is a cost of $10 per child ages 6 months - 6 years
- They require caregivers to remain with their children at all times (children cannot run free/ without your direct supervision).
- They will require you to take off your shoes so you will want to wear or bring socks.
- They do allow snacks in a designated room in the back (not in the play areas).

You can find more information here:

results.description:
THIS PRACTICE SESSION WILL RESUME NEXT WEEK

Details
● Meet on a weekly basis
● At the Gampopa Center
● There are new people at every class, drop in anytime.
● Everyone is welcome!
● $3 donation requested;

● Happiness Hour consists of a short talk and guided relaxing meditation to help us increase our peaceful good heart. It is an ideal way to unwind after work and recharge for a great evening ahead
● A weekly mindfulness meditation sitting group. This group welcomes beginners and those who have found it difficult to meditate in the past.
● A sitting group is a place to come to get support for your ongoing practice, sit together with others on the same path, and deepen your understanding of what it is to meditate. We provide the space and atmosphere for a rich community of ongoing learning for those passionate about a mindfulness lifestyle.
● There will be rotating topics for discussion and a typical evening will include 2 or 3 rounds of meditation, discussion, Q&A, and other practices to train the mind and awaken the heart.
● While we appreciate on-time arrival, if you come a little late don’t worry, please simply enter quietly and mindfully, as a meditation will likely be underway. You are welcome at any time!
● First time at one of our meditation classes? Here’s what to expect.
● Typically we begin with some introduction, and then the facilitator guides a gentle, relaxing meditation that helps us to access our natural potential for inner peace, a clear mind, and happiness.
● The facilitator then gives a practical explanation of some aspect of Buddhist meditation and practice, followed up by another short meditation to take the teaching to heart so we are confident to apply it to our daily life.
● Then there is usually time for a short discussion and/or questions and answers.

These sessions will be led by Karen Lorenz, a student of Lama Phurbu Tashi Rinpoche.
results.name: CANCELLED Meditation Happiness Hour

results.description:
Join us and bring a whole-foods, vegan (no animal products) dish to share with 6-8 people. After dinner, there will be a presentation about organic and GMO foods. Genetically Modified Organisms (GMOs) involve genetic modifications by forcing genes from one species into another entirely unrelated species. Come learn:
•Are organic foods non GMO?
•Are organic foods worth the extra price?

results.description:
David O. Stewart writes “straight” histories about the American past, as well as historical novels. How do research methods differ depending upon the type of book to be written? Does the fiction writer look to different sources than the historian does? And how has the digital revolution changed research for both? David Stewart will describe the different research processes that apply to fiction and nonfiction writing during this monthly History Happy Hour.

After practicing law for many years, David O. Stewart began to write history, too. His first book, The Summer of 1787: The Men Who Invented the Constitution, was a Washington Post bestseller and won the Washington Writing Award as Best Book of 2007. Two years later, Impeached: The Trial of President Andrew Johnson and the Fight for Lincoln’s Legacy, was called “by all means the best account of this troubled episode” by Professor David Donald of Harvard. The Society of the Cincinnati awarded David its 2013 History Prize for American Emperor, Aaron Burr’s Challenge to Jefferson’s America, an examination of Burr’s Western expedition, which shook the nation’s early foundations. The Lincoln Deception, an historical mystery about the John Wilkes Booth Conspiracy, was released in late August 2013. Bloomberg View called it the best historical novel of the year, while Publishers Weekly said it was an “impressive debut novel.” Madison’s Gift: Five Partnerships That Built America,was released in February, 2015. The Washington Post called it a portrait “rich in empathy and understanding” by “an acknowledged master of narrative history.”

Tickets are $15 for museum members and for pre-registration or $20 at the door. Enjoy happy hour drinks and light refreshments.

Visit www.sandyspringmuseum.org for details and to purchase tickets.
results.name: History Happy Hour: Writing Historic Fact and Historic Fiction

group.name: History Happy Hours at Sandy Spring Museum!

We rescheduled the drumming circle last time because of the weather. I am glad Sherri will be available to do it on Friday evening this time and on a New Moon. This can be very therapeutic and the native Americans believe that the drum is the heart beat. This is the first time and I am hoping to continue this through the summer months, based on attendance.
Bring your prayers and intentions. We encourage you to bring your drums or other percussion instruments. If you don't have any, we have plenty to share. A drum circle is a fun experience that is accessible to anyone who wants to participate regardless of age or experience level. The goal is to achieve oneness with a group, not rhythmic perfection. This is not a professional group, we do this for fun and relaxation. Children are welcome and I have purchased some instruments specifically for kids. Shamanism is the oldest spiritual belief system on earth. Drumming has been a method of group healing and achieving unity since the beginning of time. Studies have shown that drumming accelerates physical healing, boosts the immune system and produces feelings of well-being.
Meet at the Gazebo outside- WEATHER PERMITTING!
Donation $10
Children must be accompanied by an adult 12 under $1

WHY YOU SHOULD ATTEND
Attendees will learn step-by-step techniques, best practices and important information to enable you to avoid costly legal and business pitfalls. These interactive sessions give attendees the opportunity to ask questions, share their stories and get direct answers regarding the success of their business.

Seating will be limited to support an interactive, informative conversation among serious business owners.

AGENDA FOR WORKSHOP ONE: May 7th 2016
(Agenda order may change slightly due to time constraints) Admission is $39.

8:30am: Check-In & Light Breakfast
A light breakfast provided by one of our key sponsors.

9am: 30 Key Steps for Growing Businesses
A candid discussion on focus groups, marketing, budgeting, contracts, choosing a business entity, registering with the IRS and state, team building, business plans and successfully growing your business.

10am: Marketing Essentials & Elevator Pitches
A fun workshop on choosing and reaching a target market and developing your 15 second description of your products and services. Everyone will have numerous opportunities to practice their pitches and ask questions about their particular target market.

11:30am: Funding & Legal Best Practices
A serious discussion about funding sources and how to avoid common issues that cause businesses to fail.

SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS:

*Venroy July, Esq.- Corporate Attorney at Hogan & Lovells
Venroy July is a senior associate at Hogan & Lovells in their corporate practice. His practice includes a wide range of corporate and finance matters, with a particular focus on mergers and acquisitions, public and private equity offerings, debt offerings and general corporate governance. He has worked on private and public company transactions, including mergers, stock and asset purchases and sales, joint ventures, proxy contests, debt and equity offerings, and business restructurings.

*Will Holmes- Founder of WHC & Founder of Baltimore Professionals & Entrepreneurs
Will Holmes has over 15 years of experience in: business operations leadership, project management; workflow management; technical training; software end-user training; soft skills training; business process re-engineering and improvement; workflow development and process transformation; new technology implementations; successful software point releases; project requirements gathering; business process mapping; web design; and business plan and marketing plan creation. Will founded Will Holmes Consulting in Baltimore, Maryland in 2006 as a business management and technology consulting firm focused on providing complete solutions for growing businesses. Will Holmes Consulting specializes in business operations process improvement, implementation of new technology, and customized technical and soft skills training. results.description:
*** If you are attending this practice, please don't forget to sign up on our website by clicking the "Sign Up" link at the top. ***

The BDBC open practices occur every Wednesday from 6:15 to 7:30 PM and Saturday mornings from 8:30 to 9:30. For those of you that have never participated in dragon boating before, here are a few handy things to know to make your experience more enjoyable: 

- The club has never flipped a boat during practice so the odds of you going completely into the water are very low but please keep in mind that there can be a significant amount of splashing on board. Chances are good that you will get a bit wet while we're out there so you should dress accordingly. Wear clothes that you won't mind getting wet in.

- As far as footwear goes, some people like to paddle barefoot, some like to wear flip flops and others like water shoes of some sort. Sneakers and shoes like that are usually a bad idea since they can get pretty wet and uncomfortable pretty quickly. - Although the club normally tries to have a cooler available with bottled water, it's not a bad idea to bring a bottle with you to practice to take on the boat. During the summer months especially, it can get pretty warm out there and we like to hydrate regularly.

- The seats on the boat are not the softest in the world and your butt will most likely be a bit sore after practice. To soften the seat a bit, it is recommended that you bring some sort of pad. There are many different options that our club members use and some of the most popular are gardening knee pads and folded up bath mats. A bunched up towel will suffice as well. - Other handy items that you may want to bring with you are sunglasses, sunscreen, gloves and a hat.

- Life jackets and paddles are provided to everyone.

- There is not room on the boat to bring much else with you so please leave everything in your car/on land.

- There is a secure waterproof bag available to collect everyone's car keys when we get on the boat.

- The point of our open practices, is to get people familiar with the sport of dragon boating while demonstrating proper technique and timing. Our coaches are excellent at explaining the mechanics of paddling a dragon boat and working towards the ultimate goal of having all twenty paddlers working as a single unit to move as efficiently through the water as possible, all while having a whole lot of fun! More information can be found at<a>www.baltimoredragonboatclub.com.</a> Hope to see you there!
results.how_to_find_us: Head towards the water taxi stop near the UA campus.  You should see us all huddled up in that area.
results.name: Open Practice

We are putting together a team to join this fitness competition. It should be fun and supports a great cause! Plus, it's at Under Armour's Fancy gym :) If you decide to register, let me know! We have about 4 women registered so far and we'll have a team registered for the fit olympics as well.

https://www.facebook.com/events/266491117015246/ Cancer sucks. FX Fitness is teaming up with Ulman Cancer Fund to raise money for the construction of their new UCF House - a free housing option for cancer patients, their families, and caregivers, during their time of treatment, located in East Baltimore.
Come to the UAPC UA HQ to try out a variety of fitness classes, and then compete as a team in Fit Olympics. Compete in a series of events to win points. The team with the most points at the end is named ultimate winner.
Event will also include silent auction, local vendors, and food and beverages.
Kids are welcome!

10:00-12:00 - Fit Olympics

MEETUP #1: 3809 Crain Hwy, Bowie, MD[masked] US
MEETUP #2 9608 Fort Meade Rd, Laurel, MD 20707

MEETUP #3 "Jump-in [7487 - 7463] Brink Rd, Laytonsville, MD[masked] (MEETUP #47408 Shockley Drive Frederick, MD[masked]) then on to Gettysburg

LUNCH AT Appalachian Brewing Company of Gettysburg, 401 Buford Ave, Gettysburg, PA 17325 (Highly recommended by KU Rider-Renita) The Battle of Gettysburg was a turning point in the Civil War, the Union victory that ended General Robert E. Lee's second and most ambitious invasion of the North. Often referred to as the "High Water Mark of the Rebellion", Gettysburg was the war's bloodiest battle with 51,000 casualties. It was also the inspiration for President Abraham Lincoln's immortal "Gettysburg Address".

THE DAVID WILLS HOUSE

The David Wills House in downtown Gettysburg welcomes visitors to the downtown area. David Wills' home was the center of the immense clean-up process after the Battle of Gettysburg. In a second-floor bedroom, President Abraham Lincoln put the finishing touches on the Gettysburg Address - the speech transformed Gettysburg from a place of sorrow to the symbol of our nation's "new birth of freedom." The museum features six galleries including the restored office where David Wills coordinated post-battle recovery efforts and invited a President to deliver "a few appropriate remarks," and the famous Lincoln bedroom where the President finished revising his Gettysburg Address.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the big green bike this is a kickstands up event Tammy from KU  will be leading

results.description:
Come join Laurel's flagship event for food, fun, and entertainment!​﻿

Mayor Craig A. Moe has announced that Laurel’s annual Main Street Festival will be held Saturday, May 7th from 9:00am – 4:00pm. Mayor Moe commends the Laurel Board of Trade for its hard work every year to ensure that visitors from close and far enjoy a day of entertainment, food, vendors, music and activities. Laurel is proud of its small town roots and close knit community, which is evidenced by the Main Street Festival. Main Street will be completely closed to vehicular traffic between Route 1 South and 7th Street allowing thousands of people to stroll up and down Main Street enjoying numerous food vendors, bands and arts and crafts. The Festival will start with the parade which will begin at 9:00 a.m. Each year this event draws thousands of people who enjoy the day’s festivities and visiting Main Street businesses. ​ If you have any questions about the Main Street Festival, please call the Laurel Board of Trade at[masked]-0838.

http://laurelboardoftrade.wix.com/lbot342#!main-street-festival/c17h0

results.description: Carpool to Hagerstown at 9:30 am.  It is essential that you call or text me by May 6 so I can contact you to see whether you can drive or will be a passenger and also so I can make the appropriate reservation at the restaurant. My cell is[masked]-8305.  This is a popular annual trip--see the flyer with pictures and details at www.firstplacesingles.org.  Our trip includes a guided tour of the Hager House, built in 1739 and beautifully restored ($3 donation), the large city park with its beautiful gardens, swans on the lake, and the Washington County Museum of Fine Arts, also a smaller art gallery--bring your cameras! At 1:30 pm we'll regroup in the museum parking lot and carpool to the Schmankerlstube, an award winning Bavarian restaurant.  If it is nice weather, we'll gather in the biergarten, although inside is lovely too. After lunch, (3:30-4 PM?) we'll carpool back to Catonsville.  Optional happy hour at Matthews 1600 where others may join us.
results.how_to_find_us: meet at the back of Matthews Parking lot--we have permission to park all day
results.name: Hagerstown, history and art museums, gardens, biergarten

results.description:
This is a moderate pace ride for those wishing a fun but challenging ride. You do not need to be a member of Potomac Pedalers to ride with us, but consider joining! See Potomac Pedalers website for more information. C Pace is average 10-12 mph and CC pace averages 12-14. 

We will start at the fire station in Sandy Spring, then head up into Brookeville and Howard County, with moderate but short hills and rolling hills. Two ride leaders, one for each pace. Rest stop at mile 11 at the High's. Optional post-ride lunch at the Urban BBQ (BBQ, beer, veggie burgers) near start point, on Rt 108. The start is Sandy Spring Fire Station, 17921 Brooke Rd, Sandy Spring, MD 20860; meet at far left parking lot. There is no rest room at the start, but Passions Bakery Café is 1/2 mile down the road

Cue sheets ​will be provided but can also be found in Potomac Pedalers cue sheet library (Olney Meander Reverse).
results.how_to_find_us: At the fire station parking lot, far end to the left

results.description:
Come out and play!!  Enjoy the beach; get some sand between your toes (and maybe in your ears if you like to dive.)

Baltimore Beach Volleyball would love for you to come check out one of Baltimore's hidden gems, seven courts of beach volleyball with water views! Most Saturdays and Sundays, you can come brush up on your volleyball skills, learn some new ones, and make some new friends along the way playing coed doubles, fours, and sixes volleyball.  Baltimore Beach welcomes all skill levels, so don't worry if it has been a few years since you have bumped, set, spiked a volleyball.

None of your friends play volleyball, but you want to play?  No problem!  If you don't have enough people to make a team you can just join in with other teams, and people, already there.

Cost for all day "Drop-In" play is $5 for those who don't play in the league (or $50 for the year, which includes a Baltimore Beach T-shirt), and its FREE for 2016 league members.

Once you arrive just check in with Baltimore Beach staff at the "trailer" office by court 1,  to pay the $5 fee and receive an explanation of the 'Drop-In Play system' and rules. 

Beach chairs, umbrellas, coolers* and dogs on a leash are all welcome! *No visible alcohol is permitted in city parks. 

For more information on Baltimore Beach, check out the website


If you find that you like the feel of sand between your toes while getting some exercise and making new friends, and want to play during the week, you can also join a Baltimore Beach Volleyball league.  Leagues play every night of the week,  more information can be found at: Information on Baltimore Beach Leagues. Registration for the summer session opens May 26th!
results.how_to_find_us: Located in the Inner Harbor between the MD Science Center and the Rusty Scupper

Refresh and rejuvenate with a free community service initiative to introduce people to breathing & meditation techniques that have a calming effect on the mind and reduce stress. In this 60-minute interactive session, participants develop insight on how to reduce negative emotions - anger, regret, sadness, anxiety and fear - that eat up our energy and time putting an unnecessary burden on our efforts. This workshop is also an introduction to the Art of Living Course.

During the workshop participants will experience:


• Breathing techniques that increase energy and vitality


• A guided meditation


• The connection between our breath, emotions, mind, body & the Self


• Discussion about the tendencies of the mind

Participants will be introduced to tools to chart a new course to healthier, happier, stress-free living.

results.description:
Learn about planets while getting some exercise! Note: This is a no-host meetup. Feel free to use the comments area to find other group members at the event.


Website: http://www.friendsofaatrails.org/planet_walk.htm

Event details: 

PLANET WALK

SATURDAY, MAY 7, 2016
Professional astronomers, amateur experts and student volunteers will guide walkers on a tour of our Solar System, beginning at the Sun Station in Glen Burnie, through the eight planets and out to the dwarf planet, Pluto, at the Ranger Station in Severna Park.


Eighth Annual Planet Walk Scheduled for Saturday May 7

On Saturday May 7, 2016, the Friends of Anne Arundel County Trails, the Anne Arundel Community College Astronomy Club, the Astrophysics Science and Planetary Science Divisions of the NASA/Goddard Space Flight Center and the Universities Space Research Association have teamed up to offer a day of public programs focusing on our solar system.  The events will include a Planet Walk on the Baltimore & Annapolis Trail and an illustrated evening presentation at Anne Arundel Community College, followed by a Stargazing Party at the AACC Observatory.  Attendance and parking are free for all events.  This year’s event is dedicated to the late Elizabeth Wyble, a past president of the Friends of Anne Arundel County Trails who played an indispensible role in the creation of the Planet Walk and its sculptural monuments to the planets.

The events will kick off at 10:00 am with a Planet Walk along a 4.7-mile segment of the B&A Trail between Glen Burnie and Severna Park.  This segment of the Trail features two sculptures and ten planet stations representing the Sun and the planets of the Solar System, with each sculptural stainless steel marker spaced at that  planet’s proportional distance from the Sun.  Between 10:00 am and 2:30 pm, planetary scientists and astronomers from NASA/Goddard, area colleges and universities and local astronomy clubs will be at each of the planet stations to provide information and handouts concerning that planet and to answer questions. 

Participants can walk or bicycle the 4.7-mile course between the Sun Sculpture, located just south of Aquahart Road behind Harundale Plaza in Glen Burnie and the Pluto sculpture, located just north of the Earleigh Heights Road Ranger Station in Severna Park. Ample  parkingis located adjacent to the beginning of the Planet Walk in Glen Burnie.  It is recommended that participants start at the Sun Station. This event will be cancelled in the event of heavy rain.  For participants seeking a shorter or less time-consuming experience, the six planets between the Sun and Saturn can be visited in the first 1 1/4 miles of the Planet Walk between Harundale Plaza and Marley Station Mall.   

Special evening events are also scheduled at Anne Arundel Community College’s Arnold campus.  At 7:30 pm an illustrated program will be presented in Annex A, Room 101. Annex A is located at the south end of Parking Lot A. Mark Kochte of the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory will give a presentation titled “New Horizons – the Adventure to Pluto” which will reflect new research and photography from that mission’s 2015 flyby.  Mr. Kochte is a Mission Analyst for New Horizon’s 9.5 year voyage to Pluto.

Following the presentation, there will be a question and answer session as well as drawings for the daytime Planet Walk raffle.  Raffle entries are available to all Planet Walk participants who complete the 4.7-mile planetary journey.  This indoor multimedia program will be presented regardless of weather conditions.

Finally, beginning at 8:30 pm, the AACC Astronomy Club will host a Stargazing Party at the College Observatory.  The Observatory is located outside Parking Lot B on the Arnold campus.  Participants will have the opportunity to use the Observatory’s telescopes with the assistance of Astronomy Club members and may also bring their own telescopes.  The Stargazing Party will be cancelled in the event that overcast conditions or inclement weather prevent making celestial observations. 

The activities of May 7 will give participants a chance to gain greater insight into the makeup of our solar system as well as to learn about some of the ongoing research which has brought us new and exciting revelations and amazing photography of Pluto and its moons.  Additional information about the day’s events is also available on Facebook and at www.friendsofaatrails.org.
results.name: Walk the Solar System

results.description:
Proverbs 29:18King James Version (KJV)

18 Where there is no vision, the people perish

Are you stuck in a life/career rut?  Have you started projects, but failed to finish them?  Have you been putting off starting your own business, writing that book, making that career transition, or just ready to make a brand new start in your life?  Are you about to graduate from college without any idea of the next step you should take?  Are you newly single again?  You're in the right place!   We all need encouragement and motivation, but that is not going to help you to reach your life and career goals and objectives if you don't have a workable plan to achieve them.  That is why it is crucial to write your vision down and develop a plan to bring it to fruition.  Let's us share some tools, techniques, inspiration and accountability so you can finally make progress and significant movement towards designing the life and career that you want!

Our First Meetup will be by phone, but subsequent meetings will take place in a venue in the College Park/Hyattsville/Beltsville/Laurel area.  We will provide the call-in information and secure code number as we get closer to the date.   Can't wait to meet all of you!  Let's get to work on making your dreams, your reality!  Be sure to send an email address where we can keep you posted on the Meetup details!
results.name: Write The Vision!

results.description:
This meetup is specifically designed to add a missed component in cancer care and complete recovery – the self-care and self-healing in body, mind and spirit. Everyone may have cancer cells in his/her body some time in life, all cancer therapies work through our internal environment that let cancer grow in the first place. Our self-healing practice targets at change of the pro-cancer environment (physically and mentally). For many patients who have recovered through qigong practice and self-care, having cancer was no longer a life disaster, but a turning point or a gift toward a better, healthier and longer life.

Our first meetup will have a 30-minute of Power-point introduction to Cancer Self-Healing, followed by some basic Qigong skills and practice. Hopefully we will find time for everyone to meet more frequently...

Please watch this Youtube video before you come so that we can discuss about it and answer your questions.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6-7PLtfZwfA

Note: A $10 fee is optional, or a voluntary donation. You don't have to pay to participate in this meetup.... :)

results.description:
** Note the date change ** 

Come join us on May 7th as we are planning to hold several sessions and challenges for kids of all ages and abilities.

This will include challenges designed for everyone from those new to programming to the more experienced young coder looking to work in Scratch and more advanced programming languages.

In addition, we will have two groups this week focused on Lego Mindstorm Robots and Arduino for a select number of kids interested in micro-controllers.   


The kids from all groups will have the opportunity to showcase their work to the group and show what they have learned at the end of each session. We have a full fall agenda planned with CoderDojo Annapolis events scheduled until now and the end of the school year. 

About Coder Dojo Annapolis


CoderDojo is a free, volunteer-led, community based programming club for young people between 7 and 17, where they can  learn how to code, develop websites, apps, programs, games and explore technology in an informal and creative environment. 


If I miss the first events, can we join later? Absolutely - anyone can join any anytime and they will be welcome and given the opportunity to get involved.


Do I need a laptop? No, but while we will have several laptops available to borrow, we do encourage kids who have access to a laptop to come with their own.

Does a parent need to be present? We encourage all parents to be involved and be present at all sessions. For children 12 years and under, a parent MUST stay in the room at all times and for children under 10, we encourage the parent to plan to participate in the session. For children 13 and above, the parent can choose to leave but it should be understood that we are in no way liable or responsible for your child. (see Legalese below)

Who are the mentors? Our mentors are adults working in various tech fields, educators and university students. We have a number of mentors and volunteers who have stepped up, but more are always needed and welcome (older kids are welcome to join and help as well - great on a resume!)

We look forward to seeing many of you. If you have any questions, please contact David Blackburn at [masked]

IMPORTANT NOTICE - By RSVPing for CoderDojo Annapolis on Meetup.com, you are consenting to participate in the CoderDojo workshop(s) on this basis.

LEGALESE VERSION (borrowed and adapted from other CoderDojos):

• All CoderDojo mentors are offering their services voluntarily in their individual capacity. The host venue bears no formal relationship, responsibility or liability whatsoever in connection with the CoderDojo organizers or mentors and is offering its facilities to the CoderDojo Annapolis on a discretionary and good faith basis.

• All CoderDojo mentors are offering their services voluntarily and on a good faith, not-for profit, basis. Neither the CoderDojo mentors nor the host venue bear any responsibly or liability whatsoever or howsowever arising, for any loss or damage, whether direct or indirect, arising from any advice or instruction, or lack of advice or instruction, offered by any CoderDojo mentor.

• We are participating in this workshop on a fully voluntary basis and do so at our own risk. We are free to follow or not to follow the CoderDojo mentors’ advice as we decide. Neither the host venue nor the CoderDojo mentors bear any responsibly for any damage that may be caused as a result of their instruction or lack of instruction.

For example, if our laptop crashes or is damaged due to the downloading of any particular software suggested by a CoderDojo mentor, then we, and only we, bear full responsibility for any such damage and we hereby hold harmless and indemnify the host venue and the CoderDojo mentors and organizers for and against any claim for damages howsoever arising.

PHOTOGRAPHY: I understand that CoderDojo volunteers and news agencies may from time to time take photos or video of the CoderDojo sessions to be published for editorial or promotional purposes. If I do not want my child photographed, I understand that I need to make this known to the organizers at the beginning of the session. They will try to ensure that I am notified before any photography or videotaping for publication begins so I may remove my child during that time.

RESPONSIBILITY FOR PARTICIPANTS: Each child must be accompanied by an adult who signs in for him / her and is responsible for him / her during the session; this adult must stay for the entire session, no exceptions are permitted.

results.description:
Let's take a hike along the Patapsco River Valley and check out Cascade Falls!


The route: This is a two-part hike, returning to the meetup point between parts for a short break as needed.


• For the first part, we'll depart from the meetup point, cross to the left bank of the Patapsco River on the suspension footbridge and head upstream along the Grist Mill Trail to Ilchester Rd, recrossing the river on the Grist Mill Walking Bridge. After walking perhaps a 100 meters SW on Ilchester Rd we'll reenter the Gristmill Trail and return to our starting point on the right bank of the Patapsco River. The first part is a loop of about 2.5 miles. The trail surface on the left bank is paved and fairly level, while the right bank is mostly dirt with gentle inclines and a few rocks, roots and logs. The two suspension bridges across the Patapsco River have wooden decks supported by cables and are perhaps 50 feet above the water.


• For the second part, we'll hike SW up the Cascade Trail to Morning Choice Trail, passing Cascade Falls and making several stream crossings along the way. At Morning Choice Trail we turn SE and hike SE and NE through the woods along Morning Choice Trail, Old Track Loop, and a connector trail to the Ridge Trail, where we'll turn NW and return to our starting point along the Ridge Trail and River Rd. The second part is a loop of about 2.6 miles. The trail surface is dirt with moderate inclines and rocks, roots, logs, and several stream crossings and footbridges.


The total hike is just over 5 miles of smiles, easy to moderate difficulty, and should take about 2.5 hours to complete.


Google map: http://tinyurl.com/jgktc3q</a>

How to get there: 


• The approximate address of the parking area is 6199 River Rd, Elkridge, MD 21075. You may wish to use GPS coordinates in your nav device: GPS[masked], -76.750964.

• From the I-495 Capital Beltway (either direction), take exit 22A onto the Baltimore-Washington Pkwy / MD-295 N and drive NE about 18 miles. Take the exit onto I-195 W toward I-95/Catonsville and drive NW 1.9 miles. Take exit 3 to merge onto US-1 S/Washington Blvd toward Elkridge. After merging onto US-1 S take the next right onto South St, then an immediate left onto River Rd. (You'll see a Patapsco park sign.) Follow River Rd to a T-junction with Gun Rd and turn left onto Gun Rd to cross the Patapsco River. After crossing the bridge turn right as Gun Rd becomes River Rd, and follow River Rd almost 2 miles to the parking area, on your left just after passing the restrooms. See <a href="https://goo.gl/maps/wTgWsT89QgJ2">https://goo.gl/maps/wTgWsT89QgJ2


What to bring: Water, comfy shoes with some tread on them, and your furry friend if desired (leashes please). Insect repellent and sunscreen are recommended, and a poncho or whatever in case of showers. Bring your park entry fee in cash (see below).


Cost (April-October): On weekdays, $2/vehicle, out-of-state residents $4/vehicle. On weekends, $3/person, out-of-state residents $5/person. If the park entrance toll booth is unoccupied, put your entrance fees in the envelope and put the hangtag in your car window.


Weather: The forecast is overcast and a high of 66F, with a 24% chance of showers at hike start, decreasing into the afternoon. Updates here:http://tinyurl.com/zlhp7zj

Advisory: As a reminder, this is an adult group, and you are ultimately responsible for your own safety and well-being during events. No one under 18 years of age is allowed at this event, either as members or as guests, to include babies in carriers and/or strollers.

Administrative stuff: There is a restroom and drinking fountains at the meetup point.


Notes:

• Patapsco Valley State Park, 8020 Baltimore National Pike, Ellicott City, MD 21043,[masked]-5005. http://tinyurl.com/qzuj8pj

• Patapsco Valley State Park Avalon Area trail map: http://tinyurl.com/z2o7kz4


• Patapsco Valley State Park use fees: http://tinyurl.com/jfa4yzq
results.how_to_find_us: We'll assemble in front of the restrooms on River Rd at GPS 39.24075, -76.74978
results.name: Patapsco Valley State Park

results.description:
[masked] for Gregg . We will paddle 10-12 miles on the Beautiful Magothy River and Sillery Bay , and poke our heads into the North end of the waters around Gibson Island, stopping at the scenic Dobbins Island Beach for a rest and snack. Of course afterward we will travel to a nearby location ( http://www.thedeepcreekrestaurant.com/ ) for a frosty beverage and tasty lunch/snack !

For Advanced Beginners : This event is for those who have been on longer trips (up to 10 miles, full day outings), have some experience with Level 2 conditions (Protected water near shore, up to 10 Knot winds, up to 1 foot waves, up to 1 knot currents) , winds, waves and currents, and have good rescue and group-paddling skills.


Spriggs Farm Park is a new (opened last November) access point for kayakers, in a county with few access points, opened in part due to the efforts of Chuck McMillin and Lisa Arrowsmith and others. It has a beautiful soft launch and parking . It's probably unfamiliar to many Water Edge members.

It's locked and gated and I will get there one hour early to open things up. The entrance can be tricky to find . Take Route 2 to College Parkway. Turn onto College Parkway. Turn left onto Shore Acres Road. Turn left onto Bayberry (it's easy to miss this turn). Stay right at the Y intersection to continue on Bayberry. Spriggs Farm Park is on the right. They have recently moved the entrance to back by the old farmhouse There is now a good signage there. Once you're inside the gate follow the signs past the farmhouse and through the outbuildings down to the put in.

Bay temps are warming up but cold gear will still be needed (wetsuits NOT mandatory unless conditions worsen between now and then .


Bring a dry change of clothes in case of a capsize.

*********PLEASE review these excellent "cold water gear/ clothing " articles before paddling. ***********

http://www.paddling.net/guidelines/showArticle.html?95

http://www.paddleboston.com/advice/dressforcoldwater.php

"There are three rules to remember when dressing for cold weather:

No cotton.
It soaks up water and holds it against your skin, leaving it worthless as an insulator and heavy as a layer. A worthless, worthless fabric in the water.

Layers help trap heat and fend off water. Remember "wick, warmth, and weather" as you arrange your layers: light wicking fabrics first, then warm insulating sweaters or fleeces, and finally an waterproof outer layer to protect you from the elements.

No cotton; seriously."

Kayaking involves known and unanticipated risks including physical injury and death that cannot be eliminated without jeopardizing the essential quality of the sport. Group organizers and leaders and other members cannot pay continuous attention to all participants. Participants must be responsible for their own safety. Don’t overestimate your skills and abilities. Take instructional courses to learn about paddling technique, safety, self-rescue and hypothermia. Be aware of the tides, currents and weather conditions that will affect your safety on the days you paddle. Cooperate with group organizers, leaders and other members to insure your own safety as well as the safety of others and make it the fun, enjoyable day on the water it should be.

Welcome to Warrior Meditation! These meditation sessions are secular and available to anyone wishing to meditate. All experience levels are welcome. During this session, I'll be offering 4 rounds of 10 to 15 minutes of Shamatha Meditation (also known as Calm Abiding, or Mindfulness meditation). If you are new to meditation and you would like to discuss the technique one on one, please send me a message, and we can schedule time before meditation to go over the technique. After the meditation session we discuss the meditation experience, and also take in select readings from a variety of meditation masters. The focus on most of our reading sessions is about using what we learn in meditation in every day life situations. 

Cheers!

Terri

results.description:
My plan is to park at Patterson Park, walk to Canton Waterfront Park for water festivities. Then, walk back to Patterson Park for mud festivities.

Cell:[masked]

Be sure to read the spectators guide!

http://www.avam.org/news-and-events/events/kinetic-sculpture-race.shtml

"Each May, the American Visionary Art Museum (AVAM) hosts the East Coast Kinetic Sculpture Race Championship around Baltimore’s Inner Harbor. Kinetic Sculptures are creative human-powered works of art custom-built for the race.
Although they're lots of fun to watch, the Kinetic Sculptures must be able to traverse 14 miles of city roads and be amphibious. The eight-hour race includes a dip into Baltimore harbor and a trip through mud and sand pits at Patterson Park. The organizers expect about 40 entries from teams that have invested a lot of imagination, time, and money building these inventive contraptions that must bear the brunt of the race all afternoon.

It's all in fun to create a colorful spectacle of artistic design, clever engineering, and human bravado by the many contestants who eagerly propel their machines along Baltimore's streets and waters. The crowd becomes part of the event with their own outrageous costumes and cheering. There are awards presented at the end for everything from best artistic design to worst entry into the water at the Canton ramp."

About The Race:
From the American Visionary Art Museum—a race of wacky, imaginative, TOTALLY HUMAN-POWERED WORKS OF ART, DESIGNED TO TRAVEL ON LAND, THROUGH MUD, AND OVER DEEP HARBOR WATERS, constructed out of used bicycles, gears, and parts, created by a lunatic genius who tinkers around in the garage or backyard (do you know this person?)! The machines can be simple, small crafts, piloted by only one brave soul, or they can be over 50 feet long, extremely well-engineered, sophisticated vehicles powered by a team of pilots. Pilots ("Kinetinauts") compete for the most coveted GRAND MEDIOCRE EAST COAST CHAMPION AWARD (finishes right in the middle), and the highly prized NEXT TO THE LAST AWARD (finishes, well, next-to-last), and other serious trophies including ART, ENGINEERING, BEST BRIBES and more. The all-day race kicks off at 11am at American Visionary Art Museum. For all official Kinetic Sculpture Race updates, follow: KineticBaltimore.com.

15 mile Race route!

http://kineticbaltimore.com/ksr/downloads/2016KsrSpectatorsGuide.pdf?v=3
